Markov Perfect Equilibrium

Overview¶

This lecture describes the concept of Markov perfect equilibrium.

Markov perfect equilibrium is a key notion for analyzing economic problems involving dynamic strategic interaction, and a cornerstone of applied game theory.

In this lecture we teach Markov perfect equilibrium by example.

We will focus on settings with

  • two players
  • quadratic payoff functions
  • linear transition rules for the state

Other references include chapter 7 of L Ljungqvist and T J Sargent. Recursive Macroeconomic Theory. MIT Press, 4 edition, 2018.

using LinearAlgebra, Statistics, QuantEcon

Background¶

Markov perfect equilibrium is a refinement of the concept of Nash equilibrium.

It is used to study settings where multiple decision makers interact non-cooperatively over time, each seeking to pursue its own objective.

The agents in the model face a common state vector, the time path of which is influenced by – and influences – their decisions.

In particular, the transition law for the state that confronts each agent is affected by decision rules of other agents.

Individual payoff maximization requires that each agent solve a dynamic programming problem that includes this transition law.

Markov perfect equilibrium prevails when no agent wishes to revise its policy, taking as given the policies of all other agents.

Well known examples include

  • Choice of price, output, location or capacity for firms in an industry (e.g., [EP95], [Rya12], [DS10]).
  • Rate of extraction from a shared natural resource, such as a fishery (e.g., [LM80], [VL11]).

Let’s examine a model of the first type.

Example: A duopoly model¶

Two firms are the only producers of a good the demand for which is governed by a linear inverse demand function

p=a0−a1(q1+q2)(49.1) p = a_0 - a_1 (q_1 + q_2) \tag{49.1}p=a0​−a1​(q1​+q2​)(49.1)
(1)

Here p=pt p = p_t p=pt​ is the price of the good, qi=qit q_i = q_{it} qi​=qit​ is the output of firm i=1,2 i=1,2 i=1,2 at time t t t and a0>0,a1>0 a_0 > 0, a_1 >0 a0​>0,a1​>0.

In (49.1) and what follows,

  • the time subscript is suppressed when possible to simplify notation
  • x^ \hat x x^ denotes a next period value of variable x x x

Each firm recognizes that its output affects total output and therefore the market price.

The one-period payoff function of firm i i i is price times quantity minus adjustment costs:

πi=pqi−γ(q^i−qi)2,γ>0,(49.2)\pi_i = p q_i - \gamma (\hat q_i - q_i)^2, \quad \gamma > 0 , \tag{49.2}πi​=pqi​−γ(q^​i​−qi​)2,γ>0,(49.2)
(2)

Substituting the inverse demand curve (49.1) into (49.2) lets us express the one-period payoff as

πi(qi,q−i,q^i)=a0qi−a1qi2−a1qiq−i−γ(q^i−qi)2,(49.3) \pi_i(q_i, q_{-i}, \hat q_i) = a_0 q_i - a_1 q_i^2 - a_1 q_i q_{-i} - \gamma (\hat q_i - q_i)^2 , \tag{49.3}πi​(qi​,q−i​,q^​i​)=a0​qi​−a1​qi2​−a1​qi​q−i​−γ(q^​i​−qi​)2,(49.3)
(3)

where q−i q_{-i} q−i​ denotes the output of the firm other than i i i.

The objective of the firm is to maximize ∑t=0∞βtπit \sum_{t=0}^\infty \beta^t \pi_{it} ∑t=0∞​βtπit​.

Firm i i i chooses a decision rule that sets next period quantity q^i \hat q_i q^​i​ as a function fi f_i fi​ of the current state (qi,q−i) (q_i, q_{-i}) (qi​,q−i​).

An essential aspect of a Markov perfect equilibrium is that each firm takes the decision rule of the other firm as known and given.

Given f−i f_{-i} f−i​, the Bellman equation of firm i i i is

vi(qi,q−i)=max⁡q^i{πi(qi,q−i,q^i)+βvi(q^i,f−i(q−i,qi))}(49.4) v_i(q_i, q_{-i}) = \max_{\hat q_i} \left\{\pi_i (q_i, q_{-i}, \hat q_i) + \beta v_i(\hat q_i, f_{-i}(q_{-i}, q_i)) \right\} \tag{49.4}vi​(qi​,q−i​)=q^​i​max​{πi​(qi​,q−i​,q^​i​)+βvi​(q^​i​,f−i​(q−i​,qi​))}(49.4)
(4)

Definition A Markov perfect equilibrium of the duopoly model is a pair of value functions (v1,v2) (v_1, v_2) (v1​,v2​) and a pair of policy functions (f1,f2) (f_1, f_2) (f1​,f2​) such that, for each i∈{1,2} i \in \{1, 2\} i∈{1,2} and each possible state,

  • The value function vi v_i vi​ satisfies the Bellman equation (49.4).
  • The maximizer on the right side of (49.4) is equal to fi(qi,q−i) f_i(q_i, q_{-i}) fi​(qi​,q−i​).

The adjective “Markov” denotes that the equilibrium decision rules depend only on the current values of the state variables, not other parts of their histories.

“Perfect” means complete, in the sense that the equilibrium is constructed by backward induction and hence builds in optimizing behavior for each firm at all possible future states.

  • These include many states that will not be reached when we iterate forward on the pair of equilibrium strategies fi f_i fi​ starting from a given initial state.

Computation¶

One strategy for computing a Markov perfect equilibrium is iterating to convergence on pairs of Bellman equations and decision rules.

In particular, let vij,fij v_i^j,f_i^j vij​,fij​ be the value function and policy function for firm i i i at the j j j-th iteration.

Imagine constructing the iterates

vij+1(qi,q−i)=max⁡q^i{πi(qi,q−i,q^i)+βvij(q^i,f−i(q−i,qi))}(49.5) v_i^{j+1}(q_i, q_{-i}) = \max_{\hat q_i} \left\{\pi_i (q_i, q_{-i}, \hat q_i) + \beta v^j_i(\hat q_i, f_{-i}(q_{-i}, q_i)) \right\} \tag{49.5}vij+1​(qi​,q−i​)=q^​i​max​{πi​(qi​,q−i​,q^​i​)+βvij​(q^​i​,f−i​(q−i​,qi​))}(49.5)
(5)

These iterations can be challenging to implement computationally.

However, they simplify for the case in which the one-period payoff functions are quadratic and the transition laws are linear — which takes us to our next topic.

Linear Markov perfect equilibria¶

As we saw in the duopoly example, the study of Markov perfect equilibria in games with two players leads us to an interrelated pair of Bellman equations.

In linear quadratic dynamic games, these “stacked Bellman equations” become “stacked Riccati equations” with a tractable mathematical structure.

We’ll lay out that structure in a general setup and then apply it to some simple problems.

Coupled linear regulator problems¶

We consider a general linear quadratic regulator game with two players.

For convenience, we’ll start with a finite horizon formulation, where t0 t_0 t0​ is the initial date and t1 t_1 t1​ is the common terminal date.

Player i i i takes {u−it} \{u_{-it}\} {u−it​} as given and minimizes

∑t=t0t1−1βt−t0{xt′Rixt+uit′Qiuit+u−it′Siu−it+2xt′Wiuit+2u−it′Miuit}(49.6) \sum_{t=t_0}^{t_1 - 1} \beta^{t - t_0} \left\{ x_t' R_i x_t + u_{it}' Q_i u_{it} + u_{-it}' S_i u_{-it} + 2 x_t' W_i u_{it} + 2 u_{-it}' M_i u_{it} \right\} \tag{49.6}t=t0​∑t1​−1​βt−t0​{xt′​Ri​xt​+uit′​Qi​uit​+u−it′​Si​u−it​+2xt′​Wi​uit​+2u−it′​Mi​uit​}(49.6)
(6)

while the state evolves according to

xt+1=Axt+B1u1t+B2u2t(49.7) x_{t+1} = A x_t + B_1 u_{1t} + B_2 u_{2t} \tag{49.7}xt+1​=Axt​+B1​u1t​+B2​u2t​(49.7)
(7)

Here

  • xt x_t xt​ is an n×1 n \times 1 n×1 state vector and uit u_{it} uit​ is a ki×1 k_i \times 1 ki​×1 vector of controls for player i i i
  • Ri R_i Ri​ is n×n n \times n n×n
  • Si S_i Si​ is k−i×k−i k_{-i} \times k_{-i} k−i​×k−i​
  • Qi Q_i Qi​ is ki×ki k_i \times k_i ki​×ki​
  • Wi W_i Wi​ is n×ki n \times k_i n×ki​
  • Mi M_i Mi​ is k−i×ki k_{-i} \times k_i k−i​×ki​
  • A A A is n×n n \times n n×n
  • Bi B_i Bi​ is n×ki n \times k_i n×ki​

Computing Equilibrium¶

We formulate a linear Markov perfect equilibrium as follows.

Player i i i employs linear decision rules uit=−Fitxt u_{it} = - F_{it} x_t uit​=−Fit​xt​, where Fit F_{it} Fit​ is a ki×n k_i \times n ki​×n matrix.

A Markov perfect equilibrium is a pair of sequences {F1t,F2t} \{F_{1t}, F_{2t}\} {F1t​,F2t​} over t=t0,…,t1−1 t = t_0, \ldots, t_1 - 1 t=t0​,…,t1​−1 such that

  • {F1t} \{F_{1t}\} {F1t​} solves player 1’s problem, taking {F2t} \{F_{2t}\} {F2t​} as given, and
  • {F2t} \{F_{2t}\} {F2t​} solves player 2’s problem, taking {F1t} \{F_{1t}\} {F1t​} as given

If we take u2t=−F2txt u_{2t} = - F_{2t} x_t u2t​=−F2t​xt​ and substitute it into (49.6) and (49.7), then player 1’s problem becomes minimization of

∑t=t0t1−1βt−t0{xt′Π1txt+u1t′Q1u1t+2u1t′Γ1txt}(49.8) \sum_{t=t_0}^{t_1 - 1} \beta^{t - t_0} \left\{ x_t' \Pi_{1t} x_t + u_{1t}' Q_1 u_{1t} + 2 u_{1t}' \Gamma_{1t} x_t \right\} \tag{49.8}t=t0​∑t1​−1​βt−t0​{xt′​Π1t​xt​+u1t′​Q1​u1t​+2u1t′​Γ1t​xt​}(49.8)
(8)

subject to

xt+1=Λ1txt+B1u1t,(49.9) x_{t+1} = \Lambda_{1t} x_t + B_1 u_{1t}, \tag{49.9}xt+1​=Λ1t​xt​+B1​u1t​,(49.9)
(9)

where

  • Λit:=A−B−iF−it \Lambda_{it} := A - B_{-i} F_{-it} Λit​:=A−B−i​F−it​
  • Πit:=Ri+F−it′SiF−it \Pi_{it} := R_i + F_{-it}' S_i F_{-it} Πit​:=Ri​+F−it′​Si​F−it​
  • Γit:=Wi′−Mi′F−it \Gamma_{it} := W_i' - M_i' F_{-it} Γit​:=Wi′​−Mi′​F−it​

This is an LQ dynamic programming problem that can be solved by working backwards.

The policy rule that solves this problem is

F1t=(Q1+βB1′P1t+1B1)−1(βB1′P1t+1Λ1t+Γ1t)(49.10) F_{1t} = (Q_1 + \beta B_1' P_{1t+1} B_1)^{-1} (\beta B_1' P_{1t+1} \Lambda_{1t} + \Gamma_{1t}) \tag{49.10}F1t​=(Q1​+βB1′​P1t+1​B1​)−1(βB1′​P1t+1​Λ1t​+Γ1t​)(49.10)
(10)

where P1t P_{1t} P1t​ solves the matrix Riccati difference equation

P1t=Π1t−(βB1′P1t+1Λ1t+Γ1t)′(Q1+βB1′P1t+1B1)−1(βB1′P1t+1Λ1t+Γ1t)+βΛ1t′P1t+1Λ1t(49.11) P_{1t} = \Pi_{1t} - (\beta B_1' P_{1t+1} \Lambda_{1t} + \Gamma_{1t})' (Q_1 + \beta B_1' P_{1t+1} B_1)^{-1} (\beta B_1' P_{1t+1} \Lambda_{1t} + \Gamma_{1t}) + \beta \Lambda_{1t}' P_{1t+1} \Lambda_{1t} \tag{49.11}P1t​=Π1t​−(βB1′​P1t+1​Λ1t​+Γ1t​)′(Q1​+βB1′​P1t+1​B1​)−1(βB1′​P1t+1​Λ1t​+Γ1t​)+βΛ1t′​P1t+1​Λ1t​(49.11)
(11)

Similarly, the policy that solves player 2’s problem is

F2t=(Q2+βB2′P2t+1B2)−1(βB2′P2t+1Λ2t+Γ2t)(49.12) F_{2t} = (Q_2 + \beta B_2' P_{2t+1} B_2)^{-1} (\beta B_2' P_{2t+1} \Lambda_{2t} + \Gamma_{2t}) \tag{49.12}F2t​=(Q2​+βB2′​P2t+1​B2​)−1(βB2′​P2t+1​Λ2t​+Γ2t​)(49.12)
(12)

where P2t P_{2t} P2t​ solves

P2t=Π2t−(βB2′P2t+1Λ2t+Γ2t)′(Q2+βB2′P2t+1B2)−1(βB2′P2t+1Λ2t+Γ2t)+βΛ2t′P2t+1Λ2t(49.13) P_{2t} = \Pi_{2t} - (\beta B_2' P_{2t+1} \Lambda_{2t} + \Gamma_{2t})' (Q_2 + \beta B_2' P_{2t+1} B_2)^{-1} (\beta B_2' P_{2t+1} \Lambda_{2t} + \Gamma_{2t}) + \beta \Lambda_{2t}' P_{2t+1} \Lambda_{2t} \tag{49.13}P2t​=Π2t​−(βB2′​P2t+1​Λ2t​+Γ2t​)′(Q2​+βB2′​P2t+1​B2​)−1(βB2′​P2t+1​Λ2t​+Γ2t​)+βΛ2t′​P2t+1​Λ2t​(49.13)
(13)

Here in all cases t=t0,…,t1−1 t = t_0, \ldots, t_1 - 1 t=t0​,…,t1​−1 and the terminal conditions are Pit1=0 P_{it_1} = 0 Pit1​​=0.

The solution procedure is to use equations (49.10), (49.11), (49.12), and (49.13), and “work backwards” from time t1−1 t_1 - 1 t1​−1.

Since we’re working backwards, P1t+1 P_{1t+1} P1t+1​ and P2t+1 P_{2t+1} P2t+1​ are taken as given at each stage.

Moreover, since

  • some terms on the right hand side of (49.10) contain F2t F_{2t} F2t​
  • some terms on the right hand side of (49.12) contain F1t F_{1t} F1t​

we need to solve these k1+k2 k_1 + k_2 k1​+k2​ equations simultaneously.

Key insight¶

A key insight is that equations (49.10) and (49.12) are linear in F1t F_{1t} F1t​ and F2t F_{2t} F2t​.

After these equations have been solved, we can take Fit F_{it} Fit​ and solve for Pit P_{it} Pit​ in (49.11) and (49.13).

Infinite horizon¶

We often want to compute the solutions of such games for infinite horizons, in the hope that the decision rules Fit F_{it} Fit​ settle down to be time invariant as t1→+∞ t_1 \rightarrow +\infty t1​→+∞.

In practice, we usually fix t1 t_1 t1​ and compute the equilibrium of an infinite horizon game by driving t0→−∞ t_0 \rightarrow - \infty t0​→−∞.

This is the approach we adopt in the next section.

Implementation¶

We use the function nnash from QuantEcon.jl that computes a Markov perfect equilibrium of the infinite horizon linear quadratic dynamic game in the manner described above.

Application¶

Let’s use these procedures to treat some applications, starting with the duopoly model.

A duopoly model¶

To map the duopoly model into coupled linear-quadratic dynamic programming problems, define the state and controls as

xt:=[1q1tq2t]anduit:=qi,t+1−qit,i=1,2x_t := \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ q_{1t} \\ q_{2t} \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad u_{it} := q_{i,t+1} - q_{it}, \quad i=1,2xt​:=⎣⎡​1q1t​q2t​​⎦⎤​anduit​:=qi,t+1​−qit​,i=1,2
(14)

If we write

xt′Rixt+uit′Qiuitx_t' R_i x_t + u_{it}' Q_i u_{it}xt′​Ri​xt​+uit′​Qi​uit​
(15)

where Q1=Q2=γ Q_1 = Q_2 = \gamma Q1​=Q2​=γ,

R1:=[0−a020−a02a1a120a120]andR2:=[00−a0200a12−a02a12a1]R_1 := \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -\frac{a_0}{2} & 0 \\ -\frac{a_0}{2} & a_1 & \frac{a_1}{2} \\ 0 & \frac{a_1}{2} & 0 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad R_2 := \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & -\frac{a_0}{2} \\ 0 & 0 & \frac{a_1}{2} \\ -\frac{a_0}{2} & \frac{a_1}{2} & a_1 \end{bmatrix}R1​:=⎣⎡​0−2a0​​0​−2a0​​a1​2a1​​​02a1​​0​⎦⎤​andR2​:=⎣⎡​00−2a0​​​002a1​​​−2a0​​2a1​​a1​​⎦⎤​
(16)

then we recover the one-period payoffs in expression (49.3).

The law of motion for the state xt x_t xt​ is xt+1=Axt+B1u1t+B2u2t x_{t+1} = A x_t + B_1 u_{1t} + B_2 u_{2t} xt+1​=Axt​+B1​u1t​+B2​u2t​ where

A:=[100010001],B1:=[010],B2:=[001]A := \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad B_1 := \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad B_2 := \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}A:=⎣⎡​100​010​001​⎦⎤​,B1​:=⎣⎡​010​⎦⎤​,B2​:=⎣⎡​001​⎦⎤​
(17)

The optimal decision rule of firm i i i will take the form uit=−Fixt u_{it} = - F_i x_t uit​=−Fi​xt​, inducing the following closed loop system for the evolution of x x x in the Markov perfect equilibrium:

xt+1=(A−B1F1−B1F2)xt(49.14) x_{t+1} = (A - B_1 F_1 -B_1 F_2 ) x_t \tag{49.14}xt+1​=(A−B1​F1​−B1​F2​)xt​(49.14)
(18)

Parameters and Solution¶

Consider the previously presented duopoly model with parameter values of:

  • a0=10 a_0 = 10 a0​=10
  • a1=2 a_1 = 2 a1​=2
  • β=0.96 \beta = 0.96 β=0.96
  • γ=12 \gamma = 12 γ=12

From these we compute the infinite horizon MPE using the following code

using QuantEcon, LinearAlgebra

# parameters
a0 = 10.0
a1 = 2.0
β = 0.96
γ = 12.0

# in LQ form
A  = I + zeros(3, 3)
B1 = [0.0, 1.0, 0.0]
B2 = [0.0, 0.0, 1.0]

R1 = [      0.0   -a0 / 2.0          0.0;
    -a0 / 2.0          a1     a1 / 2.0;
            0.0    a1 / 2.0          0.0]

R2 = [      0.0          0.0      -a0 / 2.0;
            0.0          0.0       a1 / 2.0;
    -a0 / 2.0     a1 / 2.0             a1]

Q1 = Q2 = γ
S1 = S2 = W1 = W2 = M1 = M2 = 0.0

# solve using QE's nnash function
F1, F2, P1, P2 = nnash(A, B1, B2, R1, R2, Q1, Q2, S1, S2, W1, W2, M1, M2,
                       beta=β)

# display policies
println("Computed policies for firm 1 and firm 2:")
println("F1 = $F1")
println("F2 = $F2")
Computed policies for firm 1 and firm 2:
F1 = [-0.6684661455442794 0.295124817744414 0.0758466630580742]
F2 = [-0.6684661455442794 0.07584666305807419 0.295124817744414]

Running the code produces the following output.

One way to see that Fi F_i Fi​ is indeed optimal for firm i i i taking F2 F_2 F2​ as given is to use QuantEcon.jl’s LQ type.

In particular, let’s take F2 as computed above, plug it into (49.8) and (49.9) to get firm 1’s problem and solve it using LQ.

We hope that the resulting policy will agree with F1 as computed above

Λ1 = A - (B2 * F2)
lq1 = QuantEcon.LQ(Q1, R1, Λ1, B1, bet=β)
P1_ih, F1_ih, d = stationary_values(lq1)
F1_ih
1×3 Matrix{Float64}: -0.668466 0.295125 0.0758467

This is close enough for rock and roll, as they say in the trade.

Indeed, isapprox agrees with our assessment

isapprox(F1, F1_ih, atol=1e-7)
true

Dynamics¶

Let’s now investigate the dynamics of price and output in this simple duopoly model under the MPE policies.

Given our optimal policies F1 F1 F1 and F2 F2 F2, the state evolves according to (49.14).

The following program

  • imports F1 F1 F1 and F2 F2 F2 from the previous program along with all parameters
  • computes the evolution of xt x_t xt​ using (49.14)
  • extracts and plots industry output qt=q1t+q2t q_t = q_{1t} + q_{2t} qt​=q1t​+q2t​ and price pt=a0−a1qt p_t = a_0 - a_1 q_t pt​=a0​−a1​qt​
using LaTeXStrings, Plots
gr(size=(800, 600), html_output_format=:png)


AF = A - B1 * F1 - B2 * F2
n = 20
x = zeros(3, n)
x[:, 1] = [1 1 1]
for t in 1:n-1
    x[:, t+1] = AF * x[:, t]
end
q1 = x[2, :]
q2 = x[3, :]
q = q1 + q2         # total output, MPE
p = a0 .- a1 * q     # price, MPE

plt = plot(q, color=:blue, lw=2, alpha=0.75, label="total output")
plot!(plt, p, color=:green, lw=2, alpha=0.75, label="price")
plot!(plt, title="Output and prices, duopoly MPE")
Loading...

Note that the initial condition has been set to q10=q20=1.0 q_{10} = q_{20} = 1.0 q10​=q20​=1.0.

To gain some perspective we can compare this to what happens in the monopoly case.

The first panel in the next figure compares output of the monopolist and industry output under the MPE, as a function of time.

The second panel shows analogous curves for price

Here parameters are the same as above for both the MPE and monopoly solutions.

The monopolist initial condition is q0=2.0 q_0 = 2.0 q0​=2.0 to mimic the industry initial condition q10=q20=1.0 q_{10} = q_{20} = 1.0 q10​=q20​=1.0 in the MPE case.

As expected, output is higher and prices are lower under duopoly than monopoly.

Exercises¶

Exercise 1¶

Replicate the pair of figures showing the comparison of output and prices for the monopolist and duopoly under MPE.

Parameters are as in duopoly_mpe.jl and you can use that code to compute MPE policies under duopoly.

The optimal policy in the monopolist case can be computed using QuantEcon.jl’s LQ type.

Exercise 2¶

In this exercise we consider a slightly more sophisticated duopoly problem.

It takes the form of infinite horizon linear quadratic game proposed by Judd [Jud90].

Two firms set prices and quantities of two goods interrelated through their demand curves.

Relevant variables are defined as follows:

  • Iit I_{it} Iit​ = inventories of firm i i i at beginning of t t t
  • qit q_{it} qit​ = production of firm i i i during period t t t
  • pit p_{it} pit​ = price charged by firm i i i during period t t t
  • Sit S_{it} Sit​ = sales made by firm i i i during period t t t
  • Eit E_{it} Eit​ = costs of production of firm i i i during period t t t
  • Cit C_{it} Cit​ = costs of carrying inventories for firm i i i during t t t

The firms’ cost functions are

  • Cit=ci1+ci2Iit+0.5ci3Iit2 C_{it} = c_{i1} + c_{i2} I_{it} + 0.5 c_{i3} I_{it}^2 Cit​=ci1​+ci2​Iit​+0.5ci3​Iit2​
  • Eit=ei1+ei2qit+0.5ei3qit2 E_{it} = e_{i1} + e_{i2}q_{it} + 0.5 e_{i3} q_{it}^2 Eit​=ei1​+ei2​qit​+0.5ei3​qit2​ where eij,cij e_{ij}, c_{ij} eij​,cij​ are positive scalars

Inventories obey the laws of motion

Ii,t+1=(1−δ)Iit+qit−SitI_{i,t+1} = (1 - \delta) I_{it} + q_{it} - S_{it}Ii,t+1​=(1−δ)Iit​+qit​−Sit​
(19)

Demand is governed by the linear schedule

St=Dpit+bS_t = D p_{it} + bSt​=Dpit​+b
(20)

where

  • St=[S1tS2t]′ S_t = \begin{bmatrix} S_{1t} & S_{2t} \end{bmatrix}' St​=[S1t​​S2t​​]′
  • D D D is a 2×2 2\times 2 2×2 negative definite matrix and
  • b b b is a vector of constants

Firm i i i maximizes the undiscounted sum

lim⁡T→∞ 1T ∑t=0T (pitSit−Eit−Cit)\lim_{T \to \infty}\ {1 \over T}\ \sum^T_{t=0}\ \left( p_{it} S_{it} - E_{it} - C_{it} \right)T→∞lim​ T1​ t=0∑T​ (pit​Sit​−Eit​−Cit​)
(21)

We can convert this to a linear quadratic problem by taking

uit=[pitqit]andxt=[I1tI2t1]u_{it} = \begin{bmatrix} p_{it} \\ q_{it} \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad x_t = \begin{bmatrix} I_{1t} \\ I_{2t} \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}uit​=[pit​qit​​]andxt​=⎣⎡​I1t​I2t​1​⎦⎤​
(22)

Decision rules for price and quantity take the form uit=−Fixt u_{it} = -F_i x_t uit​=−Fi​xt​.

The Markov perfect equilibrium of Judd’s model can be computed by filling in the matrices appropriately.

The exercise is to calculate these matrices and compute the following figures.

The first figure shows the dynamics of inventories for each firm when the parameters are

δ = 0.02
D = [ -1  0.5;
     0.5   -1]
b = [25, 25]
c1 = c2 = [1, -2, 1]
e1 = e2 = [10, 10, 3]
3-element Vector{Int64}: 10 10 3

Inventories trend to a common steady state.

If we increase the depreciation rate to δ=0.05 \delta = 0.05 δ=0.05, then we expect steady state inventories to fall.
